abstract.p: Exposure to Radon (222Rn) especially indoors has been identified as an important factor that could result in a health hazard, especially increase in risk of lung cancer. Assessment of the risk can only be done with accurate information on the radon level to which the people are exposed. This work was designed to measure indoor radon level in some offices in the Faculty of Science, University of Ibadan, using electret passive environmental radon monitor (E-PERM). Measurements were made at 54 locations in five departments of the faculty. Indoor radon concentrations in these Departments were found to vary from 39.70 to 126.77 Bq·m−3 with an average mean of 65 ± 20 Bq·m−3. The results obtained showed variation with ventilation and type of building materials. The average indoor radon concentration obtained was below the indoor radon concentration action level (148 Bq·m−3) recommended by Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), hence no remedial action is required. The work however established the applicability of the technique for a much wider scope of indoor radon survey in the country.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Radon-222 is a naturally occurring radioactive gas (T1/2 = 3.8 days) from radioactive decay of radium in the uranium series. It is found everywhere in soil, rock and water. It is the heaviest of the noble gases with atomic number 86. It decays by alpha activity. Its character as a noble gas allows it to spread through the atmosphere without undergoing chemical reaction [1]. It can diffuse through the soil and rock and can be detected up to a level of 10 to 20 ppm in soil [2]. It can get into any type of buildings; homes, schools, offices and hospitals and results in a high indoor level when it seeps into the dwelling space through openings such as foundation cracks, loose fitting pipes, slab joints or block walls [3]. The major source of radon in building is the soil beneath the building. Radon concentration in a building vary in time and space depending on the area soil exposed and local geology, building materials and foundation and level of household water supply [4]. Some other factors that can influence the indoor activity concentration of radon and their daughters are temperature, pressure, humidity, ventilation and the lifestyle of the occupants [5,6]. Reduced ventilation may enable radon and its decay products to build up to levels that are orders of magnitude above the outdoors levels [7]. Exposure to radon has been identified as one of the major factors that could lead to increased risk of lung cancer. This health risk arises from the inhalation and ingestion of short-lived solid decay products of radon (Po-218 and Po-214) of which major fractions are retained in the lung to release alpha radiation directly to the tissue [8]. The health risk increases as level of radon concentration and length of exposure increases. Inhaled radon is the second leading cause of cancer, smoking being the most common pathway.

Measurement of indoor radon concentration is important because the radon dose constitutes more than 50% of the total dose to human, including those from other natural sources [8,9]. In most parts of the world, radon levels in homes and work places are known through constant monitoring [10,11]. However, in Nigeria, data are quite scarce on this important environmental health issue. As a pioneering effort in indoor radon studies in Nigeria, this present study was undertaken to determine the indoor radon concentration levels in some offices in the Faculty of Science, University of Ibadan. It is expected that this lay the basis for a possible national radon survey in Nigeria. The objective of the work is to determine and evaluate the radon concentration levels in order to determine whether remedial action is required.

sec.title: Materials and Method
sec.p: In this study, 54 offices in five departments, namely Mathematics, Geology, Physics, Chemistry and Zoology, were selected in the faculty for radon concentration measurement. Offices located at ground and first floors of each building in the department were chosen. The departments and offices were selected randomly. The Electret Passive Environmental Radon Monitor (Rad Elec Inc. 5714C Industry Lane Frederick Maryland 21701) used in this work consists of electrets discs as the radon detector, an ion chamber and a voltage reader. The radon monitoring units were placed in the offices at approximately 1 m (breathing zone) above the floor, 30 cm from exterior walls where there is no opening for free air exchange. Care was taken to ensure the units were free of disturbance from wind and displacement by occupants. The units were left for a minimum exposure period of 1 week.

The electret ion chamber is a small integrating device designed for both short- and long-term exposures. The short-term device used in this work consists of a 210 mL conducting plastic (‘S’ chamber) containing the electrets. The electrets have high sensitivity that they can respond to low radon level within a short time. The radon gas passively diffuses into the chamber through filtered inlets and the alpha particles emitted by the decay products of radon ionize air molecules. The ions produced inside the chamber volume are collected onto the surface of the electrets causing a reduction of its surface charge and hence its voltage decreases in proportion to the integrated radon concentration [12]. A voltage reader known as Surface Potential Electret by Rad Elec Inc (SPER-1) reader was used to measure the electrets surface voltage.

Using appropriate calibration factors and exposure time, the mean radon concentration (Rnc) in Bq·m−3 can be calculated from Equations (1) and (2) [13]: (1)CF+(A+B×(IV+FV)/2). (2)Rnc=[(IV-FV)/CFT-BG×G]37. where CF is the calibration factor which is defined as the decrease in electret voltage when a specific electret and a chamber are exposed for 1 day at a concentration of 37 Bq·m−3, IV and FV are the initial and final electrets voltages, respectively, T is the exposure time in days; BG is the gamma background dose rate in µSv/h as measured by a calibrated survey meter. A, B and G are the calibration constants of the electrets chamber and gamma conversion constant, respectively. Their values in this work were given by the manufacturers according to the chamber configuration. Using the E-PERM configuration SST, A is given as 1.69776, B as 5.742 × 10−4 while G the radon concentration equivalent of 1 µSv/h of background radiation equals 3.2 Bq·m−3 [14]. Background indoor gamma radiation dose (BG) was measured with a portable and calibrated RDS-30 gamma radiation survey meter (RADoS Technology Oy- Finland; serial no- 270354) (BG in Equation 2).

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p:
Using Equation (2), the indoor radon concentration level in each of the offices surveyed was determined. The Radon concentrations in the 54 offices are presented in Tables 1 and 2 for the ground floor and first floor, respectively, in each department. The results are summarized by department and displayed graphically in Figure 1. As could be seen from Figure 1, Radon concentration was found to be lowest in Mathematics Department with an average 44 ± 3 Bq·m−3 and highest in Zoology Department with an average 94 ± 17 Bq·m−3. The average mean radon concentration in the Faculty was found to be 65 ± 20 Bq·m−3. The lower concentration observed in Mathematics Department could be attributed to good ventilation as a result of adequate and large windows of the building, while the higher concentration in Zoology Department was due to poor ventilation of some of the offices. It was observed that concentrations were higher in ground floors when compared with upper floors (Tables 1 and 2). This agrees with the reports by Kerry [15] and Virk [16] explaining that higher radon concentrations would be found at the lowest occupied part of the building as a result of the higher atomic number of radon than that of air which makes it a heavier gas with higher density in the lower floors.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A short-term indoor radon measurement has been carried out in 54 offices in the Faculty of Science, University of Ibadan. Results show variations were consistent with ventilation and type of building materials used. The average values obtained were below the recommended action level (148 Bq·m−3) of Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and hence no remedial action is required. This pioneering work can be seen as having established a reliable procedure for indoor radon concentration measurement of a wider scope in the Nigerian environment.
